page.title: 18The Wood's steam engines.
page.content: The Wood family have been involved with steam engines since 1861 when Thomas Wood bought an Aveling and Porter traction engine.In the 1870's Thomas Wood had a contract to plough the battle fields of the Franco- Prussian War.After this he increased the number and types of steam engines in the company and included ploughing engines, steam rollers and road locomotives.The road locomotives had more gears and large water tanks and were used for long road haulage.Steam lorries were used in 1902 to carry local crops to market. The steam engines were replaced after WW1 by diesel and few remain in working order.Mr.E.Wood still has two steam engines that are taken to rallies through out the S.E. Repair works at the Foundary garage are still in their Victorian condition
